idioms.sentence: Felix hadn't settled into university yet. He was finding it hard to adapt.
The city was very multi-cultural. There had been a gradual assimilation of different people.
Lois was used to living in a city. When she moved to the village it was a culture shock.
The country was a democracy where everyone could vote in the elections.
The dictator was an army general, who had overthrown the government and seized power.
Geoff decided that he was not going to vote in the election.
I work for a charity called Famine Relief.
Retail store sales are down. Internet shopping has had a huge impact on sales.
The new programme to help the homeless was aimed at dealing with social injustice.
The visitors to the art museum queued to see the new art installation.
Jenny liked the flat, but didn't plan to live there long-term.
Getting home from work was the biggest obstacle because the transport workers were on strike.
Don't worry about Julie too much. It is just a phase she is going through.
Poverty is a big problem in Africa. Many people don't have enough money to buy things like food and clothing.
He tried to prevent her from going, but she really wanted to.
The man rowed single-handed across the Atlantic.
Mike was starving, he hadn't eaten anything today.
The Titanic sunk on its maiden voyage.
A small air-conditioner unit uses a lot of energy to cool a room.
They were impressed with the body-builder at the gym.
He had fallen over and broken a bone in his leg.
He was always having fun; in fact he was a bit of a clown.
She was very small and as light as a feather.
The shop assistant only let her take one garment into the changing room.
My brother was juggling three apples and he dropped them all.
Let's go down to the river and mess about on the water.
Rupert had an average-sized waist. He could always buy his suits off the peg.
It was an open microphone show and the audience were allowed to perform.
I learned to row in a small boat last summer.
Learn how to fly a kite and do stunts and tricks.
